title: Usage of AsyncGetCallTrace leads to livelock in 'getSendSlotsFromSignature'

milestone.title: Release 0.51 (Java 8, 11, 17, 21) Apr refresh
milestone.description:
jdk8u452
11.0.27
17.0.15
21.0.7

Code split: Feb 21
M1: Published
M2: Starting asap
GA start: Apr 15
GA delivery: TBD

body:
## Problem description
When using profiler that calls AsyncGetCallTrace in a signal handler, the profiled application locks up sooner or later.

Inspection of the locked up application in gdb reveals the following stacktrace and an attempt to resume the execution is unsuccessful as the thread is blocked in `getSendSlotsFromSignature`:
```
(gdb) thread 101
[Switching to thread 101 (Thread 0x7f4612627700 (LWP 4187263))]
#0  0x00007f468f249a9c in getSendSlotsFromSignature () from /home/bits/.sdkman/candidates/java/11.0.24-sem/lib/default/libj9jit29.so
(gdb) bt
#0  0x00007f468f249a9c in getSendSlotsFromSignature () from /home/bits/.sdkman/candidates/java/11.0.24-sem/lib/default/libj9jit29.so
#1  0x00007f468f22e6b2 in jitWalkStackFrames () from /home/bits/.sdkman/candidates/java/11.0.24-sem/lib/default/libj9jit29.so
#2  0x00007f468faded66 in walkStackFrames () from /home/bits/.sdkman/candidates/java/11.0.24-sem/lib/default/libj9vm29.so
#3  0x00007f469405ef36 in protectedASGCT () from /home/bits/.sdkman/candidates/java/11.0.24-sem/lib/default/libjvm.so
#4  0x00007f468f9f53c9 in omrsig_protect () from /home/bits/.sdkman/candidates/java/11.0.24-sem/lib/default/libj9prt29.so
#5  0x00007f469405f244 in AsyncGetCallTrace () from /home/bits/.sdkman/candidates/java/11.0.24-sem/lib/default/libjvm.so
#6  0x00007f4665b49d05 in Profiler::getJavaTraceAsync (this=0x7f46908c5b30, ucontext=0x1154240, frames=0x7f4691594eb0, max_depth=512, java_ctx=0x1154160, truncated=0x1154123) at /home/bits/go/src/github.com/DataDog/java-profiler/ddprof-lib/src/main/cpp/profiler.cpp:424
#7  0x00007f4665b4affe in Profiler::recordSample (this=0x7f46908c5b30, ucontext=0x1154240, counter=10000000, tid=4187263, event_type=0, call_trace_id=0, event=0x11541f0) at /home/bits/go/src/github.com/DataDog/java-profiler/ddprof-lib/src/main/cpp/profiler.cpp:722
#8  0x00007f4665b4f12f in CTimer::signalHandler (signo=27, siginfo=0x1154370, ucontext=0x1154240) at /home/bits/go/src/github.com/DataDog/java-profiler/ddprof-lib/src/main/cpp/ctimer_linux.cpp:223
#9  <signal handler called>
#10 0x00007f468f221834 in fast_jitMethodMonitorEntry () from /home/bits/.sdkman/candidates/java/11.0.24-sem/lib/default/libj9jit29.so
#11 0x00007f468f231eab in jitMethodMonitorEntry () from /home/bits/.sdkman/candidates/java/11.0.24-sem/lib/default/libj9jit29.so
#12 0x00000007345e5c80 in ?? ()
#13 0x00000007346d54a8 in ?? ()
#14 0x0000000670004d98 in ?? ()
#15 0x00000006700045a8 in ?? ()
#16 0x000000067086c488 in ?? ()
#17 0x00007f4613ace6b5 in ?? ()
#18 0x00000001c0c16d38 in ?? ()
#19 0x0000000734639060 in ?? ()
#20 0x0000000670004d98 in ?? ()
#21 0x00000007346d54a8 in ?? ()
#22 0x0000000000000000 in ?? ()
(gdb) next
Single stepping until exit from function getSendSlotsFromSignature,
which has no line number information.
^C
Thread 1 "java" received signal SIGINT, Interrupt.
[Switching to Thread 0x7f46940e1300 (LWP 4100003)]
__pthread_clockjoin_ex (threadid=139941108295424, thread_return=0x7ffd38af7c98, clockid=<optimized out>, abstime=<optimized out>, block=<optimized out>) at pthread_join_common.c:145
145     pthread_join_common.c: No such file or directory.
```

This particular stacktrace is from Java 11.0.24 but the same behaviour is observed on 8.0.422, 17.0.12 and 21.0.4

## Steps to reproduce
1. Download Datadog tracer/profiler agent (https://github.com/DataDog/dd-trace-java/releases/tag/v1.42.1)
2. Download Renaissance benchmark (https://github.com/renaissance-benchmarks/renaissance/releases/download/v0.15.0/renaissance-mit-0.15.0.jar)
3. Run profiling session like `java -javaagent:<pathto>/dd-java-agent-1.42.1.jar -Ddd.profiling.enabled=true -Ddd.profiling.ddprof.enabled=true -Ddd.profiling.upload.period=10 -Ddd.profiling.start-force-first=true  -jar <path-to>/renaissance-mit-0.15.0.jar akka-uct -r 50000` - mind you, the lock up is usually not happening immediately, but within 15-20 minutes it is guaranteed, according to my experiments.

__Note__: The current version of dd-trace-java agent will not start on JDK 21.0.4 - it is a known issue and I tested 21.0.4 with a patched version of the agent.

issue.title: Default to non-ASGCT samplers on J9
issue.body:
**What does this PR do?**:
It changes the default behaviour when on J9 the non-ASGCT based samplers will be picked unless otherwise specified.

**Motivation**:
Due to [this OpenJ9 bug](https://github.com/eclipse-openj9/openj9/issues/20577) we are running the risk of getting the profiled application into live-lock when using ASGCT.

**For Datadog employees**:
- [ ] If this PR touches code that signs or publishes builds or packages, or handles
  credentials of any kind, I've requested a review from `@DataDog/security-design-and-guidance`.
- [x] This PR doesn't touch any of that.
- [x] JIRA: [PROF-10894]

Unsure? Have a question? Request a review!


[PROF-10894]: https://datadoghq.atlassian.net/browse/PROF-10894?atlOrigin=eyJpIjoiNWRkNTljNzYxNjVmNDY3MDlhMDU5Y2ZhYzA5YTRkZjUiLCJwIjoiZ2l0aHViLWNvbS1KU1cifQ

Since there's no way `getSendSlotsFromSignature` is looping infinitely, it might be the case that the stack walker is looping and calling the function repeatedly, giving the impression we're stuck there. The ASGCT stack walk has built-in protection for this, so maybe that protection needs to be moved up a bit.

The loop breaker is in the outer loop of the walker in `walkFrame` and I don't see any looping conditions in the callers of `getSendSlotsFromSignature`. `walkFrame` is not called for every kind of resolve frame, so perhaps there's a looping case. We may be able to resolve this by adding the `loopBreaker` check into the cases that do not call `walkFrame`.
I dom't see any obvious loop for resolve frames - a single one is processed then we move on to the JIT frame loop.

Send slots has been going for a while:
```
(gdb) frame 0
#0  0x00007fa183a0d39f in getSendSlotsFromSignature (signature=0x20e000d "") at sendslot.c:34
34			switch (signature[i]) {
(gdb) i local
sendArgs = 10696213
i = 10696214
```

Subsequent core shows progress:
```
#0  getSendSlotsFromSignature (signature=0x20e000d "") at sendslot.c:34
34			switch (signature[i]) {
(gdb) i local
sendArgs = 2806039
i = 2806040
```

A much later core looks like the counters have wrapped:
```
#0  0x00007fa183a0d3c1 in getSendSlotsFromSignature (signature=0x20e000d "") at sendslot.c:34
34			switch (signature[i]) {
(gdb) i local
sendArgs = 501362
i = 501363
```
`i` is `UDATA` so I can't explain how the counter could wrap without causing a GPF at some point (the code essentially walks all of the 64-bit address space looking for the terminating bracket).

issue.title: Limit iterations of signature loop

repository.description: Eclipse OpenJ9: A Java Virtual Machine for OpenJDK that's optimized for small footprint, fast start-up, and high throughput.   Builds on Eclipse OMR (https://github.com/eclipse/omr) and combines with the Extensions for OpenJDK for OpenJ9 repo.

issue.body:
Prevent potential infinite loop in getSendSlotsFromSignature.

Related: #20577

Thanks for the fix!
Let's defiitely incliude this in 0.51

The entirety of the ASGCT call is signal protected (since we're so often attempting to walk in-flight stacks which results in a crash). Your best bet might be to print to the console and capture that output in the test run.

I added [debug code](https://github.com/a7ehuo/openj9/commit/fc05f5267247bceeb48abb7cf99025e316f26d23) in `jitWalkResolveMethodFrame` to print out some information as soon as it detects the first character of the signature is invalid. That's why the retrieved `romMethodRef` and `signature` are all invalid. At the time, no method has been compiled [3]. @tajila, per the [investigation from @a7ehuo](https://github.com/eclipse-openj9/openj9/issues/20577#issuecomment-2498536743), could someone on the VM team take a look at this?

Since there's no way `getSendSlotsFromSignature` is looping infinitely, it might be the case that the stack walker is looping and calling the function repeatedly, giving the impression we're stuck there. The ASGCT stack walk has built-in protection for this, so maybe that protection needs to be moved up a bit.

The loop breaker is in the outer loop of the walker in `walkFrame` and I don't see any looping conditions in the callers of `getSendSlotsFromSignature`. `walkFrame` is not called for every kind of resolve frame, so perhaps there's a looping case. We may be able to resolve this by adding the `loopBreaker` check into the cases that do not call `walkFrame`.
I dom't see any obvious loop for resolve frames - a single one is processed then we move on to the JIT frame loop.

As far as I can see, there is no looping condition in the JIT stack walker that doesn't call `walkFrame` which contains the loop breaker. `jitWalkResolveMethodFrame` (the caller of the supposedly offending function) contains no loops that might be repeatedly calling `getSendSlotsFromSignature`.
